Third-order optical conductivity of an electron fluid

Zhiyuan Sun Department of Physics, University of California San Diego, 9500 Gilman Drive, La Jolla, California 92093, USA â€ƒâ€ƒ D. N. Basov Department of Physics, University of California San Diego, 9500 Gilman Drive, La Jolla, California 92093, USA Department of Physics, Columbia University, 538 West 120th Street, New York, New York 10027 â€ƒâ€ƒ M. M. Fogler Department of Physics, University of California San Diego, 9500 Gilman Drive, La Jolla, California 92093, USA
Abstract

We derive the nonlinear optical conductivity of an isotropic electron fluid at frequencies below the interparticle collision rate. In this regime, governed by hydrodynamics, the conductivity acquires a universal form at any temperature, chemical potential, and spatial dimension. We show that the nonlinear response of the fluid to a uniform field is dominated by the third-order conductivity tensor Ïƒ(3)superscriptğœ3\sigma^{(3)} whose magnitude and temperature dependence differ qualitatively from those in the conventional kinetic regime of higher frequencies. We obtain explicit formulas for Ïƒ(3)superscriptğœ3\sigma^{(3)} for Dirac materials such as graphene and Weyl semimetals. We make predictions for the third-harmonic generation, renormalization of the collective-mode spectrum, and the third-order circular magnetic birefringence experiments.

I Introduction

In typical metals and semiconductors electrons experience frequent collisions with impurities and phonons. The combined rate Î“d=Î“dâ€‹iâ€‹s+Î“pâ€‹hsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘subscriptÎ“ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ subscriptÎ“ğ‘â„\Gamma_{d}=\Gamma_{dis}+\Gamma_{ph} of these collisions far exceeds the rate Î“eâ€‹esubscriptÎ“ğ‘’ğ‘’\Gamma_{ee} of electron-electron scattering. However, in several pure materials the opposite case Î“dâ‰ªÎ“eâ€‹emuch-less-thansubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘subscriptÎ“ğ‘’ğ‘’\Gamma_{d}\ll\Gamma_{ee} has recently shown to be possible in a range of temperatures. Under such conditionsÂ Gurzhi (1968); AndreevÂ etÂ al. (2011) electrons behave as a fluid that obeys hydrodynamic equations.Â LandauÂ andÂ Lifshitz (1987) Evidence for the hydrodynamic behavior has been obtained from dc transport experiments with two-dimensional (2D) electron gases in GaAs deÂ JongÂ andÂ Molenkamp (1995), graphene,Â BandurinÂ etÂ al. (2016); CrossnoÂ etÂ al. (2016); Krishna KumarÂ etÂ al. (2017) and a quasi-2D metal PdCoO2subscriptPdCoO2\mathrm{PdCoO_{2}}.Â MollÂ etÂ al. (2016) These discoveries stimulated many theoretical studies.Â MÃ¼llerÂ etÂ al. (2008, 2009); PhanÂ etÂ al. ; ForcellaÂ etÂ al. (2014); BriskotÂ etÂ al. (2015); NarozhnyÂ etÂ al. (2015); PrincipiÂ andÂ Vignale (2015a, b); SunÂ etÂ al. (2016); LucasÂ etÂ al. (2016); Lucas (2017); SunÂ etÂ al. ; GuoÂ etÂ al. (2017) The conceptual simplicity of hydrodynamics arises from dealing with only a few degrees of freedom: the local temperature Tâ€‹(ğ«,t)ğ‘‡ğ«ğ‘¡T(\mathbf{r},t), chemical potential Î¼â€‹(ğ«,t)ğœ‡ğ«ğ‘¡\mu(\mathbf{r},t), and the flow velocity ğ®â€‹(ğ«,t)ğ®ğ«ğ‘¡\mathbf{u}(\mathbf{r},t). The complicated many-body collisions need not be considered explicitly. In our previous paperÂ SunÂ etÂ al. we used this hydrodynamic formalism to calculate the electrodynamic response of an electron fluid, in particular, its linear and second-order nonlinear optical conductivities. The magnitude and functional form of these quantities in the hydrodynamic regime of frequencies Ï‰â‰ªÎ“eâ€‹emuch-less-thanğœ”subscriptÎ“ğ‘’ğ‘’\omega\ll\Gamma_{ee} were shown to differ qualitatively from their counterparts in the conventional kinetic regime Ï‰â‰«Î“eâ€‹emuch-greater-thanğœ”subscriptÎ“ğ‘’ğ‘’\omega\gg\Gamma_{ee}. Here we continue this line of investigation by addressing the third-order nonlinearity, which controls, e.g., the third-harmonic generation (Fig.Â 1), the Kerr effect, and four-wave mixing.

One reason why the third-order nonlinearity warrants attention is dictated by the symmetry. In general, the electrodynamic response of a conductor is characterized by the tensors Ïƒ(n)superscriptğœğ‘›\sigma^{(n)} describing the components of the induced current proportional to the nğ‘›nth-power of the electric field. (The definition of these tensors is given in Sec.Â II). Unless the field is very strong, the nonlinear response of a material lacking the inversion symmetry is dominated by the second-order conductivity Ïƒ(2)superscriptğœ2\sigma^{(2)}. However, in centro-symmetric systems, such as graphene, Ïƒ(2)superscriptğœ2\sigma^{(2)} must vanish if the electric field is uniform, in which case the third-order conductivity Ïƒ(3)superscriptğœ3\sigma^{(3)} becomes more important.

As we show below in this paper, the derivation of the nonlinear conductivities is straightforward within a certain model that we call the Dirac fluid. This model is simple yet flexible enough to describe several types of solid-state materials. The model assumes that the quasiparticles of the system behave as Dirac fermions with the energy-momentum dispersion Îµ2â€‹(ğ©)=m2â€‹v4+ğ©2â€‹v2superscriptğœ€2ğ©superscriptğ‘š2superscriptğ‘£4superscriptğ©2superscriptğ‘£2\varepsilon^{2}(\mathbf{p})=m^{2}v^{4}+\mathbf{p}^{2}v^{2}. The massless case m=0ğ‘š0m=0 corresponds to electrons in graphene; the massive case m>0ğ‘š0m>0 is a reasonable approximation for narrow-gap semiconductors. Neglecting fermion-fermion interactions, one can readily compute the equilibrium thermodynamic parameters of this system,Â MÃ¼llerÂ etÂ al. (2008, 2009); BriskotÂ etÂ al. (2015); SunÂ etÂ al. (2016, ) such as the pressure P=Pâ€‹(Î¼,T)ğ‘ƒğ‘ƒğœ‡ğ‘‡P=P(\mu,T) and the energy density nE=nEâ€‹(Î¼,T)subscriptğ‘›ğ¸subscriptğ‘›ğ¸ğœ‡ğ‘‡n_{E}=n_{E}(\mu,T). The crucial simplification of the Dirac model is that the energy-momentum tensor of the moving fluid can be derived from that of the static one by a Lorentz transformation with vğ‘£v in lieu of the speed of light cğ‘c. [In the noninteracting case, the moving fluid is defined as the Fermi distribution of quasiparticles with the Doppler-shifted energies Îµâ€‹(ğ©)âˆ’ğ©ğ®ğœ€ğ©ğ©ğ®\varepsilon(\mathbf{p})-\mathbf{p}\mathbf{u}.] The Lorentz invariance ensures that the hydrodynamic equations of a Dirac fluid have a simple â€œrelativisticâ€ form.Â LandauÂ andÂ Lifshitz (1987); MÃ¼llerÂ etÂ al. (2008, 2009); BriskotÂ etÂ al. (2015); NarozhnyÂ etÂ al. (2015); SunÂ etÂ al. (2016, ) Precisely because vâ‰ cğ‘£ğ‘v\neq c, the solid-state systems with real Coulomb interactions are not truly Lorentz-invariant. However, the Dirac fluid should be a reasonable approximation if the Coulomb interactions are not too strong, so that Pğ‘ƒP and nEsubscriptğ‘›ğ¸n_{E} are dominated by the kinetic energy. Besides graphene, examples of such Dirac fluids may include the surface states of topological insulators and three-dimensional Dirac/Weyl semimetals.

Note that the hydrodynamics regimes probed by recent dc transport experimentsÂ BandurinÂ etÂ al. (2016); CrossnoÂ etÂ al. (2016); Krishna KumarÂ etÂ al. (2017) is less than 111-THzTHz\mathrm{THz} wide. If one wants to expand it toward higher Ï‰ğœ”\omega, it is necessary to increase Î“eâ€‹esubscriptÎ“ğ‘’ğ‘’\Gamma_{ee}, which can be done by raising electron temperature Tğ‘‡T (Fig.Â 2). This must be done without heavily increasing the electron-phonon scattering rate Î“pâ€‹hsubscriptÎ“ğ‘â„\Gamma_{ph}, which is also temperature-dependent. One possible solutionÂ SunÂ etÂ al. is to work with (steady or transient) states where electrons are â€œhotâ€ but lattice stays â€œcold.â€ Such nonequilibrium states can be created by optical pumping or electric-current heating.

At frequencies Ï‰>Î“eâ€‹eğœ”subscriptÎ“ğ‘’ğ‘’\omega>\Gamma_{ee} where the hydrodynamic theory fails, the response of the system is better described by more conventional approaches, e.g., the Boltzmann kinetic equation neglecting electron-electron collisions. Among the Dirac materials, graphene has been the most common target of such calculations. Nonlinear conductivity of graphene has been addressed in many theoretical studies.Â Mikhailov (2007, 2011); GullansÂ etÂ al. (2013); ChengÂ etÂ al. (2014); YaoÂ etÂ al. (2014); ChengÂ etÂ al. (2015); Mikhailov (2016); TokmanÂ etÂ al. (2016); ChengÂ etÂ al. (2017); ManzoniÂ etÂ al. ; WangÂ etÂ al. (2016); RostamiÂ etÂ al. (2017); SunÂ etÂ al. As discussed in our previous workÂ SunÂ etÂ al. , the differences between the hydrodynamic and kinetic regimes (Fig.Â 2) becomes conspicuous at temperatures Tğ‘‡T exceeding the chemical potential Î¼ğœ‡\mu, where graphene contains two types of carriers, electrons and thermally excited holes. In the kinetic regime, electrons and holes tend to move in opposite directions when driven by the electric field. Their contributions to the electric current add up. In the hydrodynamic regime, due to frequent interparticle collisions, all the carriers tend to move together. Hence, the electron and hole currents partially cancel. As a consequence, there is an increased effective mass per unit charge, resulting in reduced linear and second-order nonlinear conductivities.SunÂ etÂ al. In this work we show that the third-order electrodynamic response also exhibits distinct behaviors in the two regimes, in accord with this physical picture.

The remainder of the paper is organized is follows. Section II gives a summary of our main results such as the analytical formula for the third-order nonlinear conductivity of an isotropic Dirac fluid. This formula is simple and universal. It is valid for any mass mğ‘šm, chemical potential Î¼ğœ‡\mu, temperature Tğ‘‡T, and space dimension dğ‘‘d if momentum nonconserving processes can be neglected, Î“dâ†’0â†’subscriptÎ“ğ‘‘0\Gamma_{d}\to 0. We also discuss the general form of the higher nonlinear conductivities tensors Ïƒ(n)superscriptğœğ‘›\sigma^{(n)} of odd order nğ‘›n. In Sec.Â III we introduce the relativistic hydrodynamic equations and apply them to the massless case, such as graphene. In Sec.Â IV we give the derivation of Ïƒ(3)superscriptğœ3\sigma^{(3)}, including the case of an external applied magnetic field. In Sec.Â V we apply our results for Ïƒ(3)superscriptğœ3\sigma^{(3)} to computing the third harmonic generation. In Sec.Â VI we discuss the Kerr effect and its influence on the hydrodynamic collective modes of the fluid. In Sec.Â VII we compute the magnetic-field-induced third-order circular birefringence. The concluding remarks are given in Sec.Â VIII. AppendixÂ A provides a summary of the analytical expressions for the thermodynamic quantities of a massless Dirac fluid. AppendixÂ B outlines the derivation of Ïƒ(3)superscriptğœ3\sigma^{(3)} for a more realistic case of a finite scattering rate Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d}.

EquationÂ (11) is the relativistic version of the Euler equation, Eq.Â (12) is the conservation of the energy current and Eq.Â (13) is the conservation of the charge current. Since we neglect finite-qğ‘q effects in this work, we must set âˆ‡Ã—ğ„=0âˆ‡ğ„0\nabla\times\mathbf{E}=0, so that the magnetic field is considered time-independent.

Starting from Eqs.Â (11), (12) and (13) we can compute the linear and in principle, any higher-order nonlinear optical conductivities Ïƒ(N)superscriptğœğ‘\sigma^{(N)} by expanding all the dynamic variables in powers of the electric field ğ„ğ„\mathbf{E}. This procedure and its results are presented in the following sections.

III.2 Hydrodynamic regime of graphene

Hydrodynamic regime is not a phase of matter but a domain of frequency-momentum diagram [see, e.g., Fig.Â 1 of Ref.Â SunÂ etÂ al., ] where the hydrodynamic equations work well as an effective theory. This regime is defined by inequalities Î“d,Ï‰â‰ªÎ“eâ€‹emuch-less-thansubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘ğœ”subscriptÎ“ğ‘’ğ‘’\Gamma_{d},\,\omega\ll\Gamma_{ee} and qâ‰ªleâ€‹eâˆ’1much-less-thanğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘’1q\ll l_{ee}^{-1}, which can be satisfied in some pure solid-state systems. The electron-electron collision rate Î“eâ€‹eâ€‹(n,T)subscriptÎ“ğ‘’ğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘‡\Gamma_{ee}(n,T) that sets the upper bound on the hydrodynamic regime depends on temperature and doping level of the electron system. For example, in graphene, Î“eâ€‹esubscriptÎ“ğ‘’ğ‘’\Gamma_{ee} scales as âˆ¼lnâ¡(2â€‹Î¼/T)â€‹(T2/Î¼)similar-toabsent2ğœ‡ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘‡2ğœ‡\sim\ln(2\mu/T)(T^{2}/\mu) at low Tğ‘‡T and as âˆ¼Î±2â€‹Tsimilar-toabsentsuperscriptğ›¼2ğ‘‡\sim\alpha^{2}T at Tâ‰«Î¼much-greater-thanğ‘‡ğœ‡T\gg\mu with Î±âˆ¼1similar-toğ›¼1\alpha\sim 1. For a rough estimate, we connect these two formulas by a naive interpolation with the relative weights Î¼/(T+Î¼)ğœ‡ğ‘‡ğœ‡\mu/(T+\mu) and T/(T+Î¼T/(T+\mu), respectively. The corresponding boundary of the hydrodynamic domain (blue region) is shown by the upper dashed line in Fig.Â 2. The other important scattering rate shown in the same Figure is Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d}. For ultra clean graphene encapsulated in hexagonal boron nitride (hBN), the major contribution to Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d} is the electron-phonon scattering Î“pâ€‹hsubscriptÎ“ğ‘â„\Gamma_{ph}. The electron-phonon scattering suppresses the hydrodynamic behavior if Î“pâ€‹h>Î“eâ€‹esubscriptÎ“ğ‘â„subscriptÎ“ğ‘’ğ‘’\Gamma_{ph}>\Gamma_{ee}. However, our theoretical estimation of Î“pâ€‹hsubscriptÎ“ğ‘â„\Gamma_{ph} and Î“eâ€‹esubscriptÎ“ğ‘’ğ‘’\Gamma_{ee} indicates that the hydrodynamic regime of graphene is fairly large, as shown in Fig.Â 2. Furthermore, in a nonequlibrum situation where the electron system is at high temperature Tğ‘‡T while the lattice temperature Tlsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™T_{l} remains low, Î“eâ€‹esubscriptÎ“ğ‘’ğ‘’\Gamma_{ee} is enhanced while the Î“pâ€‹h=Î“pâ€‹hâ€‹(Tl,T,n)subscriptÎ“ğ‘â„subscriptÎ“ğ‘â„subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™ğ‘‡ğ‘›\Gamma_{ph}=\Gamma_{ph}(T_{l},T,n) remains small, and so the hydrodynamic window could be wider. Such a nonequlibrum situation can be realized either through optical pumpingÂ NiÂ etÂ al. (2016) or by Joule heating due to an electric current.Â SonÂ etÂ al. (2018)

Recent experimentsÂ BandurinÂ etÂ al. (2016); CrossnoÂ etÂ al. (2016); Krishna KumarÂ etÂ al. (2017); MollÂ etÂ al. (2016) explored the dc transport in several pure 2D conductors in the regime Î“dâ‰ªÎ“eâ€‹emuch-less-thansubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘subscriptÎ“ğ‘’ğ‘’\Gamma_{d}\ll\Gamma_{ee}, i.e., near the horizontal axis Ï‰=0ğœ”0\omega=0 of Fig.Â 2. These measurements revealed signatures of viscous electron flow, which manifest themselves through a combination of high viscosity Î½=v2/Î“eâ€‹eğœˆsuperscriptğ‘£2subscriptÎ“ğ‘’ğ‘’\nu=v^{2}/\Gamma_{ee} and geometrical restriction on the flow. Because of the particular focus of these studies, the lower viscosity, higher temperature regime was labeled as nonhydrodynamic. From our point of view, viscosity is just one of very many hydrodynamic phenomena rather than its essential element. Actually, in the high-temperature regime, where the electron-hole plasma becomes a more perfect fluid,MÃ¼llerÂ etÂ al. (2009) hydrodynamic effects should be of crucial importance. They are predicted to give dramatically different optical responses compared to the noninteracting kinetic theory.Â SunÂ etÂ al.

Therefore, we have proven that the third-order conductivity Ïƒ(3)superscriptğœ3\sigma^{(3)} is determined by the linear one Ïƒğœ\sigma.

For moderate magnetic field Ï‰câ‰ªÏ‰much-less-thansubscriptğœ”ğ‘ğœ”\omega_{c}\ll\omega, and the case of a single frequency Ï‰1=Ï‰2=Ï‰3=Ï‰subscriptğœ”1subscriptğœ”2subscriptğœ”3ğœ”\omega_{1}=\omega_{2}=\omega_{3}=\omega, we can expand Ïƒ(3)superscriptğœ3\sigma^{(3)} to linear order in BğµB:

Ïƒiâ€‹lâ€‹mâ€‹n(3)=iâ€‹Dh(3)Ï‰3â€‹[Î”iâ€‹lâ€‹mâ€‹n+iâ€‹4â€‹Ï‰c3â€‹Ï‰â€‹Îiâ€‹lâ€‹mâ€‹n],subscriptsuperscriptğœ3ğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ·â„3superscriptğœ”3delimited-[]subscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘–4subscriptğœ”ğ‘3ğœ”subscriptÎğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘›\displaystyle\sigma^{(3)}_{ilmn}=\frac{iD_{h}^{(3)}}{\omega^{3}}\left[\Delta_{ilmn}+i\frac{4\omega_{c}}{3\omega}\Xi_{ilmn}\right], (32)

where Îiâ€‹lâ€‹mâ€‹n=Î´lâ€‹mâ€‹Ïµiâ€‹n+Î´lâ€‹nâ€‹Ïµiâ€‹m+Î´mâ€‹nâ€‹Ïµiâ€‹lsubscriptÎğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘›subscriptğ›¿ğ‘™ğ‘šsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptğ›¿ğ‘™ğ‘›subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–ğ‘šsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘›subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–ğ‘™\Xi_{ilmn}=\delta_{lm}\epsilon_{in}+\delta_{ln}\epsilon_{im}+\delta_{mn}\epsilon_{il}.

IV.4 Analysis of Ïƒ(3)superscriptğœ3\sigma^{(3)}

The simple tensorial structure of Eq.Â (4) is a result of rotational symmetry and local equilibrium nature of an ideal charged fluid. For comparison, in the high frequency kinetic/quantum regime of graphene, the tensorial structure of Ïƒ(3)superscriptğœ3\sigma^{(3)} is more complicated due to contributions from interband transitions and disorder scattering effects.Â ChengÂ etÂ al. (2014, 2015); Mikhailov (2016) In the hydrodynamic regime, the interband transitions are suppressed by fast e-e scattering, resulting in the simple expression of Eq.Â (4).

The magnitude of hydrodynamic Ïƒ(3)superscriptğœ3\sigma^{(3)} is also different from that of the kinetic theory. Applied to graphene at T=0ğ‘‡0T=0, our result for Dh(3)superscriptsubscriptğ·â„3D_{h}^{(3)} is

Dh(3)â€‹(T=0)=g48â€‹Ï€â€‹e4â€‹vFâ„3â€‹kF=2â€‹Dk(3),superscriptsubscriptğ·â„3ğ‘‡0ğ‘”48ğœ‹superscriptğ‘’4subscriptğ‘£ğ¹superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi3subscriptğ‘˜ğ¹2superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘˜3\displaystyle D_{h}^{(3)}(T=0)=\frac{g}{48\pi}\frac{e^{4}v_{F}}{\hbar^{3}k_{F}}=2D_{k}^{(3)}\,, (33)

which is twice the third-order spectral weight Dk(3)superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘˜3D_{k}^{(3)} from the collisionless Boltzmann transport theory Mikhailov (2016); ChengÂ etÂ al. (2014); Mikhailov (2007). This difference could be measured by, e.g., third harmonic generation to be discussed in Sec.Â V.

Comparing the third-order nonlinear response with the usual linear one, we notice that the third-order current is suppressed by the parameter

Î¾=(âˆ’eâ€‹E/Ï‰mâˆ—â€‹v)2â‰ª1.ğœ‰superscriptğ‘’ğ¸ğœ”superscriptğ‘šâˆ—ğ‘£2much-less-than1\displaystyle\xi=\left(\frac{-eE/\omega}{m^{\ast}v}\right)^{2}\ll 1\,. (34)

This factor is different in the nonrelativistic and the ultrarelativistic regimes because mâˆ—superscriptğ‘šm^{*} depends on the Fermi momentum pFsubscriptğ‘ğ¹p_{F}. As a result, in the nonrelativisitic case parameter Î¾ğœ‰\xi is smaller by the factor of (vF/v)2â‰ª1much-less-thansuperscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ¹ğ‘£21(v_{F}/v)^{2}\ll 1 than the ultrarelativistic case. This factor vanishes for a system with the parabolic dispersion, which corresponds to vâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘£v\to\infty. Indeed, for such a system all nonlinearities at zero qğ‘q should be absent because of the Galilean invariance (Kohnâ€™s theorem). On the other hand, in graphene at zero temperature, which is an example of the ultrarelativistic system, mâˆ—â€‹v=pFsuperscriptğ‘šâˆ—ğ‘£subscriptğ‘ğ¹m^{\ast}v=p_{F}, so that Î¾=(Î´â€‹p/pF)2ğœ‰superscriptğ›¿ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ¹2\xi=({\delta p}/{p_{F}})^{2}. Here Î´â€‹p=âˆ’eâ€‹E/Ï‰ğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘’ğ¸ğœ”\delta p=-eE/\omega has the physical meaning of the amplitude of electron momentum oscillation caused by the electric field.

The third-order conductivity (4) diverges at the zero frequency limit, which is unphysical. In reality, the divergence is curbed by the momentum relaxation rate Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d}, similar to the first order conductivity. A simple but crude way to include the effect of the momentum relaxation is to change all the frequencies Ï‰asubscriptğœ”ğ‘\omega_{a} to Ï‰a+=Ï‰a+iâ€‹Î“dsuperscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘subscriptğœ”ğ‘ğ‘–subscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\omega_{a}^{+}=\omega_{a}+i\Gamma_{d}. However, this approach neglects the increase of entropy density due to momentum relaxation. Thus, special care needs to be taken to compute the true nonlinear dc response, as shown in Appendix B.

V Third harmonic generation

One quantity we can derive from Ïƒ(3)superscriptğœ3\sigma^{(3)} [Eq.Â (4)] is the third harmonic generation (THG) Mikhailov (2016); GiorgianniÂ etÂ al. (2016). Assume the ac electric field of the incident light is in the xğ‘¥x-direction

ğ„â€‹(t)=x^â€‹Eâ€‹(Ï‰)â€‹eâˆ’iâ€‹Ï‰â€‹t+c.c.formulae-sequenceğ„ğ‘¡^ğ‘¥ğ¸ğœ”superscriptğ‘’ğ‘–ğœ”ğ‘¡cc\mathbf{E}(t)=\hat{x}E(\omega)e^{-i\omega t}+\mathrm{c.c.} (35)

The current, which determines the observable THG signal is

ğ£(3)â€‹(t)=x^â€‹Ïƒxâ€‹xâ€‹xâ€‹x(3)â€‹(Ï‰,Ï‰,Ï‰)â€‹Eâ€‹(Ï‰)3â€‹eâˆ’iâ€‹3â€‹Ï‰â€‹t+c.c.formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ£3ğ‘¡^ğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğœ3ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğœ”ğœ”ğœ”ğ¸superscriptğœ”3superscriptğ‘’ğ‘–3ğœ”ğ‘¡cc\mathbf{j}^{(3)}(t)=\hat{x}\sigma^{(3)}_{xxxx}(\omega,\omega,\omega)E(\omega)^{3}e^{-i3\omega t}+\mathrm{c.c.} (36)

Therefore, Ïƒxâ€‹xâ€‹xâ€‹x(3)â€‹(Ï‰,Ï‰,Ï‰)subscriptsuperscriptğœ3ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğœ”ğœ”ğœ”\sigma^{(3)}_{xxxx}(\omega,\omega,\omega) represents the magnitude of the THG. This quantity is plotted in Fig.Â 3 as a function of Tğ‘‡T. Also shown in Fig.Â 3 is the prediction of the conventional theory based on random-phase approximation (RPA),Â ChengÂ etÂ al. (2015); Mikhailov (2016) which is valid in the kinetic regime. The two curves exhibit different behavior. At zero temperature, the hydrodynamic theory predicts the THG signal which is twice that of the kinetic theory. However, since Î“eâ€‹e=0subscriptÎ“ğ‘’ğ‘’0\Gamma_{ee}=0 at T=0ğ‘‡0T=0, the electron system much be in the kinetic regime (Fig.Â 2), and so the actual Ïƒxâ€‹xâ€‹xâ€‹x(3)â€‹(Ï‰,Ï‰,Ï‰)subscriptsuperscriptğœ3ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğœ”ğœ”ğœ”\sigma^{(3)}_{xxxx}(\omega,\omega,\omega) should be close to the kinetic theory value, as sketched by the dashed line. As temperature increases, Î“eâ€‹e=0subscriptÎ“ğ‘’ğ‘’0\Gamma_{ee}=0 grows, and the system will experience a crossover from the kinetic to hydrodynamic regime at certain Tâˆ—superscriptğ‘‡âˆ—T^{\ast}. This crossover temperature is determined by Î“eâ€‹eâ€‹(n,Tâˆ—)=Ï‰subscriptÎ“ğ‘’ğ‘’ğ‘›superscriptğ‘‡âˆ—ğœ”\Gamma_{ee}(n,T^{\ast})=\omega. As temperature increases further, the hydrodynamic third-order optical weight drops as Dh(3)âˆ(mâˆ—)âˆ’3âˆTâˆ’9proportional-tosubscriptsuperscriptğ·3â„superscriptsuperscriptğ‘šâˆ—3proportional-tosuperscriptğ‘‡9D^{(3)}_{h}\propto(m^{\ast})^{-3}\propto T^{-9} due to the thermal enhancement of the hydrodynamic effective mass mâˆ—â€‹(n,T)superscriptğ‘šâˆ—ğ‘›ğ‘‡m^{\ast}(n,T). Therefore, the THG drops much faster than what the conventional kinetic theory would predict.

VI The Kerr effect and the demons

The Kerr effect refers to the change of the effective permittivity of a medium due to the third-order nonlinearityLandauÂ andÂ Lifshitz (1984); Boyd (2008). For a 2D charged Dirac fluid, this effect is more conveniently described as the shift of the effective conductivity. One manifestation of the Kerr effect is the renormalization of the frequency of the collective modes in a strong optical field. In the kinetic regimes these modes are the familiar plasmons.Â Mikhailov (2017); GiorgianniÂ etÂ al. (2016) In the hydrodynamic regime, they are the demons.Â SunÂ etÂ al. (2016, )

In general, to describe the collective modes, we need to study response at a finite qğ‘q. For small enough qğ‘q, we can approximate the result using q=0ğ‘0q=0 quantities, as follows. The charge density fluctuation could be represented by means of the Fourier amplitude ÏÏ‰,qsubscriptğœŒğœ”ğ‘\rho_{\omega,q}:

Assume qğ‘q is in the x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x} direction. VII Third order circular birefringence

In the presence of an applied magnetic field, there is a finite second term âˆÏ‰cproportional-toabsentsubscriptğœ”ğ‘\propto\omega_{c} in Eq.Â (32), which causes the third-order circular birefringence. As in Sec.Â IV.3, let us consider a 2D system subject to a normally incident monochromatic light of frequency Ï‰ğœ”\omega with the electric field polarized in the xğ‘¥x-direction. The generated third-order current has frequency Ï‰s=3â€‹Ï‰subscriptğœ”ğ‘ 3ğœ”\omega_{s}=3\omega and has a nonzero yğ‘¦y-component

jxâ€‹(3â€‹Ï‰)subscriptğ‘—ğ‘¥3ğœ”\displaystyle j_{x}(3\omega) =Ïƒxâ€‹xâ€‹xâ€‹x(3)â€‹Ex3â€‹(Ï‰)=iâ€‹Dh(3)â€‹3Ï‰3,absentsubscriptsuperscriptğœ3ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ¸3ğ‘¥ğœ”ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ·â„33superscriptğœ”3\displaystyle=\sigma^{(3)}_{xxxx}E^{3}_{x}(\omega)=iD_{h}^{(3)}\frac{3}{\omega^{3}}\,,
jyâ€‹(3â€‹Ï‰)subscriptğ‘—ğ‘¦3ğœ”\displaystyle j_{y}(3\omega) =Ïƒyâ€‹xâ€‹xâ€‹x(3)â€‹Ex3â€‹(Ï‰)=iâ€‹Dh(3)â€‹3Ï‰3â€‹(4â€‹iâ€‹Ï‰c3â€‹Ï‰).absentsubscriptsuperscriptğœ3ğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ¸3ğ‘¥ğœ”ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ·â„33superscriptğœ”34ğ‘–subscriptğœ”ğ‘3ğœ”\displaystyle=\sigma^{(3)}_{yxxx}E^{3}_{x}(\omega)=iD_{h}^{(3)}\frac{3}{\omega^{3}}\left(\frac{4i\omega_{c}}{3\omega}\right)\,. (42)

In the dissipationless limit, Ï‰ğœ”\omega is real, and jysubscriptğ‘—ğ‘¦j_{y} has a Ï€/2ğœ‹2\pi/2 phase difference relative to jxsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘¥j_{x}. Therefore, the third harmonic light will be elliptically polarized with the principal axis along xğ‘¥x. Its ellipticity, conventionally denoted by tanâ¡Î¸ğœƒ\tan\theta, is given by

tanâ¡Î¸=|jyjx|=43â€‹Ï‰cÏ‰.ğœƒsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘—ğ‘¥43subscriptğœ”ğ‘ğœ”\displaystyle\tan\theta=\left|\frac{j_{y}}{j_{x}}\right|=\frac{4}{3}\frac{\omega_{c}}{\omega}\,. (43)

Therefore, the ellipticity scales as Ï‰c=eâ€‹B/mâˆ—â€‹csubscriptğœ”ğ‘ğ‘’ğµsuperscriptğ‘šâˆ—ğ‘\omega_{c}=eB/m^{\ast}c, which decays with temperature if the carrier density nğ‘›n is fixed. This is illustrated by Fig.Â 5 for the case of graphene. From Eq.Â (26), there is also circular birefringence in the linear response, with tanâ¡Î¸=Ï‰c/Ï‰ğœƒsubscriptğœ”ğ‘ğœ”\tan\theta=\omega_{c}/\omega, which differs only by the constant numerical factor 4/3434/3. It is also plotted in Fig.Â 5, for an easy comparison.

VIII Discussion

We showed that the third-order nonlinear conductivity Ïƒ(3)superscriptğœ3\sigma^{(3)} of a Dirac fluid has a universal functional form for any mass, chemical potential, temperature, and space dimension. It is remarkable that the third-order and the linear conductivities are simply related through Eqs.Â (5) and (31). Although we have used graphene as an example in the numerical calculations, our formulas, e.g., Eqs.Â (4) and (5), hold for any Lorentz-invariant Dirac fluid. As such, these formulas should be a good approximation to surface states of topological insulators and Dirac/Weyl semimetals, provided they are in the hydrodynamic regime. We also studied the field-induced renormalization of the dispersion of the collective modes (demons) and the third-order circular birefringence in the presence of a static magnetic field.

In the future it would be interesting to investigate hydrodynamics of non-Dirac fluids, that is, systems without the Lorentz symmetry. This will be important for more realistic modeling of ultrapure solid-state systems where hydrodynamic regime has been reported (GaAs, graphene, and PdCoO2subscriptPdCoO2\mathrm{PdCoO_{2}}). In the above systems, although the quasi particle band dispersion is approximately Dirac-like, the Coulomb interaction tends to break this quasi Lorentz symmetry because it propagates with the speed of light cğ‘c rather than vğ‘£v. It would also be interesting to study nonlinear thermal transport in the Dirac fluid. The case of phonon fluids has been studied half a century agoNielsenÂ andÂ Shklovskii (1969).

After the standard symmetrization procedure, Eq.Â (54) renders Ïƒ(3)superscriptğœ3\sigma^{(3)} with dissipation. The cooling rate Î“EsubscriptÎ“ğ¸\Gamma_{E} could arise due to electron-phonon coupling and is crucial for eliminating the divergence of Ïƒ(3)superscriptğœ3\sigma^{(3)} in the dc limit. In this dc limit, due to work done by the electric field, the electron-hole fluid would be heated up by order E2/Î“Esuperscriptğ¸2subscriptÎ“ğ¸E^{2}/\Gamma_{E}, thus inducing a large correction to the current at the third order. This is a physical reason why setting Î“Eâ†’0â†’subscriptÎ“ğ¸0\Gamma_{E}\to 0 would lead to a diverging Ïƒ(3)superscriptğœ3\sigma^{(3)}.

In the dissipationless limit, Eq.Â (54) becomes Eq.Â (23). Moreover, it can be readily checked that if Î“E+2â€‹Î“k=2â€‹Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ¸2subscriptÎ“ğ‘˜2subscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{E}+2\Gamma_{k}=2\Gamma_{d}, Eq.Â (54) becomes identical to Eq.Â (23) as well. Under this condition, the fluid dynamics becomes isentropic again: the kinetic energy is lost to the environment due to momentum relaxation instead of converted into heat of the fluid.

Appendix C Relativistic Boltzmann equation

The relativistic Boltzmann equation is

(PÎ¼â€‹âˆ‚Î¼+FÎ¼â€‹Î½â€‹PÎ¼â€‹âˆ‚PÎ½)â€‹fRâ€‹(X,P)=Iâ€‹[fR],superscriptğ‘ƒğœ‡subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ¹ğœ‡ğœˆsuperscriptğ‘ƒğœ‡subscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğœˆsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘…ğ‘‹ğ‘ƒğ¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘…\displaystyle\left(P^{\mu}\partial_{\mu}+F_{\mu\nu}P^{\mu}\partial_{P_{\nu}}\right)f_{R}(X,P)=I[f_{R}]\,, (55)

Note that the space-time coordinate XÎ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğœ‡X^{\mu} and the momentum PÎ¼=mâ€‹uÎ¼superscriptğ‘ƒğœ‡ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘¢ğœ‡P^{\mu}=mu^{\mu} are covariant ones. For a given XÎ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğœ‡X^{\mu}, the distribution function fRâ€‹(X,P)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘…ğ‘‹ğ‘ƒf_{R}(X,P) can be defined as the density of world lines whose local tangent is PÎ¼superscriptğ‘ƒğœ‡P^{\mu}. Mathematically, fRâ€‹(X,P)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘…ğ‘‹ğ‘ƒf_{R}(X,P) is a scalar function defined on the tangent bundle of the d+1ğ‘‘1d+1 dimensional space-time. If we focus on one species of particle with a fixed mass mğ‘šm, then fRâ€‹(X,P)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘…ğ‘‹ğ‘ƒf_{R}(X,P) is related to the ordinary distribution function through

jÎ¼=âˆ«ğ‘‘Pâ€‹PÎ¼â€‹fRâ€‹(X,P)=âˆ«ğ‘‘ğ©â€‹(1,ğ¯)â€‹fâ€‹(t,ğ«,ğ©),superscriptğ‘—ğœ‡differential-dğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘ƒğœ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘…ğ‘‹ğ‘ƒdifferential-dğ©1ğ¯ğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ«ğ©\displaystyle j^{\mu}=\int dPP^{\mu}f_{R}(X,P)=\int d\mathbf{p}\;(1,\mathbf{v})f(t,\mathbf{r},\mathbf{p})\,, (57)
